climbs.name: Zig Zag
climbs.fa: TM Herbert and Mark Powell, 1961   FFA: Mark Powell and Bob Kamps, 1967

content.description:
This excellent climb is on the relatively narrow wall to the right of the

Open Book

. Start with the initial overhang of the Open Book, then move up and right past a bolt, and into a crack system. One or two 5.9 lieback moves are followed by easy climbing, and then a 5.9 move just before the belay (the route joins

Mechanic's Route

here). When Mechanic's Route branches off and right onto face climbing, continue up the crack. Great finger jamming leads ten or twelve feet up to a crux exit move onto the face.  Climb up to a crack above, and on to a belay.  Exit to either the right (Mechanic's Route) or left (Open Book).
Fun short traverse off Open Book's P1. Go up from the P1 belay of Open Book, and look left for a lone bolt. Finish on the rap chains for P1 of The Edge.
content.protection: One bolt, a few cams to start off in Open Book's P2.
content.location: Off P2 off the Open Book.

climbs.name: Torque Wrench
climbs.fa: Kevin Powell and Darrel Hensel, July 1993

content.description: More like a direct start to Mechanics Route this has some sporty moves on a vert face. Start like going to Green Arch but move left to clip a piton then up a narrow face with three bolts. Beware loose flakes, the good holds are solid. Trend into Mechanics Route after the third bolt. We finished on the Flashback 11a slab into the last pitch of Open Book.
content.location: In between Mechanics Route and Green Arch,

climbs.name: Open Book
climbs.fa: John Mendenhall and Harry Sutherland, September 1947 FFA: Royal Robbins and Don Wilson, 1952

content.description:
This three pitch beauty ascends a very obvious dihedral.

1) The first few moves off the deck are exciting and lead to an enjoyable first belay in a little nook.

2) The second pitch contains the business. You layback a 4" crack for 60+ feet to gain a belay either inside a little cave or right after depending on what gear you have left.

3) Pull the roof out of the alcove if that's where you set your belay, and continue up the dihedral in the left-side crack, much less steep and quite a bit easier than pitches 1 and 2. Eventually cross the slab and continue up to climb the deceptively easy roof on the right side. Top out and hike to the top of Tahquitz on easy 3rd class. Then you can hike out.
content.protection: Standard rack with a doubles in the 3" - 4" range. The crack gets too wide for an old # 4 (purple) camalot but you can easily run it a bit to a placement higher up.

content.description:
This shares the first bit of the

Open Book

and then traverses right to easier ground. The traverse move to gain the right crack is a bit interesting. Then after setting an anchor, the 2nd pitch asends a line of bulges and chickenheads without much gear. The third pitch traverses and ends in a 4th class grove with a fun topout on HUGE holds!
content.protection: Standard rack. Expect a bit of excitment on the second pitch. Walk to the top of Taquitz and go down and right for the walk off.

climbs.name: Hedgehog
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and John Rosholt, June 1994.

content.description: Crank up the steep face between The Glossary and The Hedge past 5 bolts. A small overhang above the third bolt is the crux.

Listed as 5.10d for in the book, this felt no harder than 10a. Make some easy moves and clip  a bolt under a small roof corner, get on the jugs in a layback crack a bit left, then back right on a flake. Before the flake peters out make a traverse up and left to a nice alcove and a two bolt belay.
content.protection: One bolt on and a few finger pieces and a BD #1 for the flake section.
content.location: Start just right of a tree, down from Open Book 20ft, first bolt is shared with Bookworm 12c, The Hedge, goes left on the layback jugs after the bolt.

climbs.name: Green Arch
climbs.fa: Mark Powell & Beverly Powell, 1964, FFA: Rick Accomazzo, John Long & Tobin Sorenson, 1975

content.description:
The Green Arch is one of Tahquiz's greatest climbs. It follows a striking corner to the right of the

Open Book

(5.9). An amazing climb you donÂ’t want to miss. And yes, it's sandbagged.

Pitch one: Start about 100 feet below were the arch begins and climb past a few pitons and one bolt to a small ledge where the arch begins (5.10+).

Pitch two: The crux. Stem your way up the smooth corner for about 100 feet. Except for the occasional pin scar there is no crack in the corner to help you out. Use the many fixed pitons for pro. Look for the rest on the outside of the corner about sixty feet up the pitch. The crux is when the corner starts arching right. Follow three bolts up to the belay after the corner ends (5.11c).

Pitch three: Climb the easy gully to the right all the way to the top.
content.protection: Lots of quick draws and small TCU cams. Bring a few larger pieces up to #2 as well.
content.location: To the right of Open book

climbs.name: The Glossary
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Mark Hoffman, and John Rosholt, June 1994

content.description: Begin just right of Bibliography, at a short crack that diagonals right to a dihedral that slants back left. Stem up the slick dihedral, then pull over a bulge to the right, finishing with easier face moves up to the 2-bolt belay ledge.
content.protection: 3 bolts, single rack to 3 inches for the start.

content.description: Climb halfway up the first pitch of Open Book to a obvious right facing arch 10a, which curves up and right. From here move up and right onto the face which share the belay for ZigZag and Mechanic's Route. At the start of the second pitch mantle an overhanging block on the left to a thin corner 10d, which leads to face climbing past 3 bolts up to the last belay of Open Book.
content.protection: Lots of thin to four inch.

content.description:
This is one of the most demanding face pitches on Tahquitz, on beautiful rock.

Clip the fist bolt on The Hedge, then climb straight up over a small roof (1.5 inch CD) to a fixed pin. Crank on thin edges (11d) up to a bolt, then continue on very thin edges (11c, stay right) up to a small ledge with another bolt.

From here move down and right, then up a short left-facing corner to a bolt (10a). Climb straight up the black streak to another bolt (10b) then power through the slightly overhanging crux (12b/c) up to another bolt. Climb up and left, joining the top section of The Bookend at its last bolt. A 1-inch CD is useful in the thin crack at the very top to protect the final move up to the anchor (11a).
content.protection: 7 bolts, 1 fixed pin, 1.5 inch CD, 1 inch CD.

climbs.name: Bookmark
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Charlie Peterson, July 1994

content.description: A variation finish to P2 of the Open Book. Just as you get to the finish alcove bust left under the roof with under-cling jugs, then a exciting move to the corner. Belay in the Traitor Horn alcove or finish on TH or Pearly Gates.
content.protection: Bomber .75 and #2 in the roof, small cam just around the corner.

climbs.name: The Bookend
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Charlie Peterson, July 1994.

content.description: This airy pitch starts at the 2-bolt belay 60 feet up and climbs the steep face just to right of The Edge. Climb a shallow corner via sustained 5.10 face climbing up and right past 4 bolts to a thin crack, which is the crux. A 1-inch CD is useful to protect the final step-up to the anchor.
content.protection:
4 bolts plus a 1-inch CD.

2-bolt anchor, 80 feet.

climbs.name: Bibliography
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, John Rosholt, Cheryl Basye, and Mark Hoffman, June 1994

content.description: Begin about 50 feet downhill and left of Open Book. Make a reach left to a flake, then stem up a shallow, hard to protect corner (5.10-), exiting left to an arete, then continue up slabby (5.8) and runnout face climbing up and right to a 2-bolt anchor on a nice ledge.
content.protection: Thin nuts and CDs to 1 inch.
